Thanks FrankR, yeah, I don't know why some people are so driven to support=
 their claims, and so against any rational thinking or testing of them.=C2=
=A0=C2=A0 Living up to some image they've obtained, fear, could all be reas=
ons I suppose, both for the blind debunker, and the blind believer.=C2=A0 B=
ut I also consider positive reasons, if I can all them that: the believer w=
ho wants a happier life, or to help others with their knowledge. And the sk=
eptic who wants to keep people from wasting their time or money, and so als=
o acquire a happier life.

I don't know Karen's "true" goal or plans, but a=
s I find out more, I will let you know.=C2=A0 And if there's opportunity to=
 keep the test honest or add as much good process to it as possible, I hope=
 everyone participates.



--- On Mon, 1/4/10, Frank Ratka <warrior18eii@ya=
hoo.com> wrote:

From: Frank Ratka <warrior18eii@...>
Subject: Re: [E=
VP-ITC] Big Mistake!
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
Date: Monday, January 4, 2=
010, 8:56 AM







=C2=A0



  


    
      
      
      RJ,
=C2=A0
I li=
ke your approach but just wanted to remind you that all of science (to incl=
ude testing) is based on probabilities. There is no definative proof but th=
eir is evidence. Scientific method is used to determine what is most probab=
le because there are no tests where all variables can be accounted for and =
used. A good test uses many independent variables. Also, a hypothesis is de=
signed to be disproven, not proven as most people think.
=C2=A0
This woman =
has no concept or desire (in my opinion)=C2=A0of designing a valid test to =
collect good evidence that supports any ITC claim. Honestly, I=C2=A0don't u=
nderstand why a uninformed skeptic is driven to make the claims they do. Wh=
at is their motivation? Is there some deeply embedded fear? Religious? Phil=
osophical (athiest)? Phobia? Does one of these subjects keep them from thin=
king something exists beyond their physical senses?
=C2=A0
In social psycho=
logy, the concept of the self or your identity is deeply rooted in how othe=
rs view you. She has to live up to that skeptic/debunker image she has buil=
t for herself. Some of the problems that come from this is how people justi=
fy their actions. Because of her prejudiced assumptions=C2=A0with the paran=
ormal (debunker), she may feel justified in spreading her misinformaion, th=
inking that she is protecting others from harm. She overlooks the errors in=
 her research and sees them as trivial compared to the outcome.
=C2=A0
Rega=
rds,
=C2=A0
Frank R.





From: Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com>
To: EVP-ITC@yahoog=
roups .com
Sent: Sat, January 2, 2010 2:35:09 PM
Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Big=
 Mistake!

=C2=A0 





I don't think "Objective" means what you think it m=
eans.

But the point of the test it to find a method that will allow the ev=
idence to speak for itself, and that is not subject to, well, subjective in=
terpretation.=C2=A0 I'm sure if you were involved in the testing design, th=
at could be achieved, to keep the results from being biased, and to keep ev=
eryone 'honest, as you put it.

You also said below " If a person doesn't w=
ant to hear it, they won't".=C2=A0 Yes, this could be a problem with the te=
st, unless a good test is developed, to remove that subjectivity.=C2=A0 It =
also works the other way of course:=C2=A0=C2=A0 If a person wants to hear i=
t, they will, which is just as subjectively bad, and can confound the resea=
rcher with all kinds of nonsensical results, strange messages, failed predi=
ctions, and so on.=C2=A0 Testing can be a way to better determine how to te=
ll which methods and messages are the most valid and
 promising.

I certain=
ly understand that some beliefs are essentially religious faith: people sta=
te it is true, and don't want anyone to question it.=C2=A0 And I don't want=
 to question anyone's religion (they get really mad and insulting when you =
do).

Maybe some people feel that way about EVPs.=C2=A0 I feel that this te=
chnology is instead perfectly applicable to good testing.=C2=A0 There are m=
any theories and approaches to EVP and ITC, and I think testing is the best=
 way to determine which works the best, which equipment people should spend=
 their money on, which theories they should spend most time with.=C2=A0 I'm=
 not sure why anyone would not want to determine these kinds of things.

Bu=
t I am now in contact with the testers and with Karen, and will be happy to=
 keep everyone informed of how this all goes.=C2=A0 

Rj

<div> </div>
<div>I like your approach but just wanted to remind you=
 that all of science (to include testing) is based on probabilities. There =
is no definative proof but their is evidence. Scientific method is used to =
determine what is most probable because there are no tests where all variab=
les can be accounted for and used. A good test uses many independent variab=
les. Also, a hypothesis is designed to be disproven, not proven as most peo=
ple think.</div>
<div> </div>
<div>This woman has no concept or desire=
 (in my opinion) of designing a valid test to collect good evidence th=
at supports any ITC claim. Honestly, I don't understand why a uninform=
ed skeptic is driven to make the claims they do. What is their motivation? =
Is there some deeply embedded fear? Religious? Philosophical (athiest)? Pho=
bia? Does one of these subjects keep them from thinking something exists be=
yond their physical senses?</div>
<div> </div>
<div>In social psycholo=
gy, the concept of the self or your identity is deeply rooted in how others=
 view you. She has to live up to that skeptic/debunker image she has built =
for herself. Some of the problems that come from this is how people justify=
 their actions. Because of her prejudiced assumptions with the paranor=
mal (debunker), she may feel justified in spreading her misinformaion, thin=
king that she is protecting others from harm. She overlooks the errors in h=
er research and sees them as trivial compared to the outcome.</div>
<div>&n=
bsp;</div>
<div>Regards,</div>
<div> </div>
<div>Frank R.<br></div>
